Award.AwardTitle: Cosmology with the kinematic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect: Testing fundamental physics and hydrodynamical simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop a new analysis technique to extract the large scale motions of galaxy clusters via a technique using a phenomenon called the pairwise kinematic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (kSZ) effect. This effect is due to the scattering of cosmic microwave photons in galaxy clusters. Broader impacts of the work include research training of undergraduate students, and outreach with planetariums in New York and Philadelphia to give presentations to and engage with the public on ask an astronomer nights. The proposal team will also be actively involved in the Ithaca Physics Bus, a new outreach initiative modeled on a successful program based in Arizona, which brings physics demonstrations and science experiments to schools and public events using a converted school bus to promote excitement about STEM disciplines.

The kinematic kSZ approach was used in the first detection of cluster motions in 2012 by cross-correlating Cosmic Microwave Background measurements from the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) with optical spectroscopy of luminous red galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey-III (SDSS-III). Upcoming measurements will enable more than an order of magnitude improvement on this first detection, and the project team is uniquely poised to extract cosmological information from these measurements. The project team has recently shown that upcoming kSZ measurements have the potential to provide strong constraints on modified gravity, dark energy, and neutrinos.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported research on developing new analysis techniques to measure the motions of galaxy clusters, the largest gravitationally bound objects in the Universe. These measurements have the potential to inform our understanding of the fundamental physics of our Universe. The galaxy cluster motions were measured by detecting the kinematic Sunyaev-Zel'dovich (kSZ) effect. The proposal team analyzed measurements from current observatories, namely the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) and the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, and with their collaborators made important advances towards using kSZ measurements to probe cosmological parameters, including dark energy, modified gravity, and neutrinos. These analyses were combined with hydrodynamical simulations of galaxy clusters to extract average cluster optical depths. The cluster optical depth defines how much of the cosmic microwave background light measured by telescopes like the ACT is scattered by the kSZ effect and is an important cluster property to understand for probing cosmology. Improved measurements from the ACT are now available, which will enable significant advances based on extending this work in the coming years.

Another important facet of this research program was helping to optimize observatories for future measurements of galaxy clusters, so that we can continue to improve our understanding of galaxy clusters and cosmology. The results supported by this award focus on extracting individual galaxy cluster velocities, optical depths, and temperatures as well as constraining the sum of the neutrino masses via kSZ measurements. These forecasts are helping to inform the designs of upcoming observatories, including CCAT-prime (www.ccatobservatory.org), and may inform designs for next generation surveys of the cosmic microwave background, such as CMB-S4 (https://cmb-s4.org/).

Several outreach and educational opportunities were supported by this award. These included engaging with the public through presentations and ask an astronomer events, working with the Ithaca Physics Bus team to promote excitement about STEM disciplines, and supporting training and research experiences for undergraduate researchers, educators, and high school students.
